Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: Improving Tropical Cyclone Risk Assessment by Incorporating Storm Size Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This postdoctoral fellowship award provides funding to enhance current tropical cyclone (TC) risk assessment methodology by incorporating physics-based TC size information into existing risk modeling frameworks. There is a lack of fundamental understanding of TC size and that leads to an inability to fully quantify the risk of damage from landfalling TCs. The overarching goal of the project will be to demonstrate a skillful physics-based explanation of the observed distribution of TC size, as well as of the size of an individual storm at genesis and during its lifecycle, for integration into a TC risk assessment framework. The project will make use of a combination of observations, high-resolution weather forecast model output, idealized modeling studies, and theory to elucidate the physics underlying the observed distribution of TC size. The results will then be used to develop and incorporate storm size physics into comprehensive TC risk assessments. Progress towards these objectives will be assessed by statistical verification of the skill of the size predictors in observations and weather forecast models.

The broader societal impacts of the project will be through better assessment and potentially mitigation of damage risk in both the short (e.g. emergency management) and long-term (e.g. infrastructure planning). The project will also enhance collaborative efforts between scientists and risk managers and support an early-career scientist.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF-AGS-PRF: Improving tropical cyclone risk assessment by incorporating storm size physics

PI: Daniel Chavas

Host: Ning Lin

Institution: Princeton University, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering

Period: 11/2013 – 10/2015

 

Project outcomes:

This project sought to make advances in both our understanding of the underlying physics of the size and structure of the tropical cyclone wind field and methodologies for its representation in risk assessment methodologies. Indeed, a proper estimation of risk, particularly due to wind and storm surge, depends crucially on a proper representation of the wind field. Though the physics of storm intensity, defined as the peak wind speed in the low-level circulation of the tropical cyclone, are reasonably well understood and various simple models exist to represent its variability, the radial variation of the wind field as well as its overall size remain poorly understood. Though our initial focus was on storm size, it became apparent that a proper physical understanding of storm size first requires a proper physical model for storm structure; the two together are sufficient to define the entire wind field.

During the fellowship period, PI Chavas developed a new theoretical analytical model for the radial structure of the tropical cyclone wind field. This model combined pre-existing analytical solutions for the wind field in the inner core of the storm, where rain is plentiful, and the broad outer region of the storm, where there is nearly zero rain. The result is a viable simple model not only for representing the wind structure itself but also for understanding variability in the wind field as a whole that can be used for risk analysis. This work has been captured in two journal publications in the Journal of Atmospheric Sciences:

1)     Chavas, D. R, N. Lin, and K. A. Emanuel (2015). A complete tropical cyclone radial wind structure model. Part I: Comparison with observed structure. In press.

2)     Chavas, D. R. and N. Lin (2015). A complete tropical cyclone radial wind structure model. Part II: Wind field variability. In review.

 

To define the complete wind field, the above structural model requires as input a measure of the size of the outer circulation. PI Chavas began new work towards this end. First, the statistical characterization of storm size in nature was revisited using a new near-surface oceanic wind field dataset from the QuikSCAT satellite scatterometer. This work demonstrated a strong relationship between mean storm size and the sea surface temperature difference from the tropical mean; a similar relationship had been recently identified using precipitation data. The paper is submitted to the Journal of Climate:

Chavas, D. R., N. Lin, W. Dong, and Y. Lin (2015). Observed tropical cyclone size revisited. In review.

 

Finally, PI Chavas began work on improving our fundamental understanding of storm size in an idealized global climate simulation where the surface is entirely an ocean of constant temperature, solar energy input is constant everywhere, and the dynamics are defined as if the entire Earth existed at a latitude of 10o N. The result is a world full of many tropical cyclones, which provides an excellent test bed for examining how tropical cyclones behave when there is nothing to get in their way or cause their demise. This work has been published in the Journal of Advances in Modeling Earth Systems:

Reed, K. and D. R. Chavas (2015). Uniformly-rotating global radiative-convective equilibrium in the Community Atmosphere Model, version 5. In press.
